title: Keenadu Android Firmware Backdoor: Supply Chain Compromise Embeds Multi-Stage Loader in Tablet Firmware via Signed OTA Updates, Enabling Full Remote Device Control Across 13,000+ Devices Worldwide
affected_products: Alldocube iPlay 50 mini Pro NFE tablets
Google Play apps: Eoolii, Ziicam, Eyeplus (by Hangzhou Denghong Technology Co., Ltd.)
Android devices with firmware containing modified libandroid_runtime.so

sources.name: Kaspersky Securelist - Keenadu the tablet conqueror and the links between major Android botnets
Kaspersky Press Release - Kaspersky discovers Keenadu
BleepingComputer - New Keenadu backdoor found in Android firmware, Google Play apps
The Hacker News - Keenadu Firmware Backdoor Infects Android Tablets via Signed OTA Updates
Dark Reading - Supply Chain Attack Embeds Malware in Android Devices

CSO Online - Keenadu: Android malware that comes preinstalled and cannot be removed by users

timeline.event: Earliest known infected firmware identified on Alldocube iPlay 50 mini Pro (T811M) tablets
Alldocube iPlay 50 mini Pro NFE initially ships with clean firmware, but all subsequent OTA updates through May 2024 contain Keenadu
Kaspersky initially discloses Keenadu discovery and begins detailed analysis
Kaspersky publishes full technical analysis on Securelist revealing connections to Triada, BADBOX, and Vo1d botnets
Google confirms removal of malicious Google Play apps and recommends Play Protect verification

simple_summary.what_happened: Kaspersky security researchers discovered a sophisticated Android malware called Keenadu that was embedded directly into the firmware of tablets made by multiple manufacturers, including Alldocube. The malware was integrated during the manufacturing process, meaning devices were infected before they ever reached consumers. Keenadu hides inside a critical Android system library (libandroid_runtime.so) that loads when the device boots up, allowing it to inject itself into every application the user opens. The investigation revealed that Keenadu is connected to three other major Android botnet families - Triada, BADBOX, and Vo1d - suggesting a coordinated underground ecosystem of device-level malware. Over 13,000 devices worldwide have been confirmed infected, and malicious apps carrying Keenadu modules were also found on Google Play with over 300,000 downloads.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Consumers and organizations using Android tablets from affected manufacturers, primarily Alldocube (iPlay 50 mini Pro and iPlay 50 mini Pro NFE models) and other undisclosed tablet brands. Users in Russia, Japan, Germany, Brazil, and the Netherlands are most heavily affected. Additionally, users who downloaded the camera apps Eoolii, Ziicam, or Eyeplus from Google Play (300,000+ combined downloads) from publisher Hangzhou Denghong Technology Co., Ltd. are at risk. Any organization allowing employees to use personal Android tablets for work could have corporate data exposed.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: The attackers compromise the firmware supply chain during the device build phase, embedding a malicious library (libVndxUtils.a) that modifies libandroid_runtime.so, a critical system library loaded during every Android boot sequence. Step 2: When the device starts, the backdoor injects into the Zygote process, which is the parent process for all Android applications, giving Keenadu access to every app the user opens and bypassing Android's application sandbox. Step 3: The AKServer module runs in the system_server process with maximum privileges, communicating with command-and-control servers hosted on Alibaba Cloud to receive payload delivery instructions. Step 4: Multiple specialized modules are deployed including browser search hijacking (redirecting Chrome queries), shopping cart manipulation (targeting Amazon, Shein, Temu), ad click fraud, and install monetization schemes. Step 5: The malware can also function as a full backdoor, granting attackers unrestricted remote access to all device data including banking credentials, messages, photos, location, and even Chrome incognito browsing history.
what_you_should_do: Check if your Android tablets are from affected manufacturers (Alldocube iPlay 50 mini Pro models); if so, check for firmware updates and rescan with a mobile security solution after updating
Uninstall Google Play apps Eoolii, Ziicam, and Eyeplus if installed; verify Google Play Protect is enabled on all Android devices
Look for infection indicators: check for files at /data/dalvik-cache/arm64/system@framework@vndx_10x.jar@classes.jar and AK_CPP debug tags in logcat
Disable compromised system apps via ADB if removal is not possible: adb shell pm disable --user 0 <package_name>
Consider replacing confirmed-infected devices, as firmware-level malware may persist through factory resets
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: This represents one of the most sophisticated Android supply chain compromises ever documented. Unlike typical malware that users install accidentally, Keenadu comes pre-installed in the device firmware with valid digital signatures, making it invisible to most security tools and impossible for users to remove without technical knowledge. The malware bypasses Android's core security protections - application sandboxing and the permission system - because it operates within the system runtime itself. The confirmed connection to three other major botnets (Triada, BADBOX, Vo1d) suggests a large organized ecosystem of firmware-level malware affecting potentially millions of devices beyond the 13,000 confirmed by Kaspersky telemetry. While currently used primarily for ad fraud, the backdoor capability means attackers can pivot to stealing banking credentials, corporate data, or personal information at any time.

tactics.technique_name: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
tactics.description: Malicious code injected during the firmware build phase, compromising libandroid_runtime.so before devices reach consumers via signed OTA updates
Compromises libandroid_runtime.so in the system partition, ensuring the backdoor loads on every boot and injects into every application via Zygote process
Injects into the Zygote parent process, the root of all Android application processes, gaining access to every app's memory space and bypassing sandbox isolation
Malware embedded in legitimate system libraries with valid digital signatures; implements 2.5-month activation delay and avoids Chinese locales to evade detection
Exfiltrates banking credentials, messaging app data, and authentication tokens from compromised applications via the injected client module
Grants and revokes arbitrary app permissions to access protected data including location, contacts, messages, and Chrome incognito browsing history
Transmits IMEI, MAC address, device model, and stolen data to C2 servers via AES-128-CFB encrypted communications hosted on Alibaba Cloud CDN

detection_guidance.summary: Detection requires checking for firmware-level indicators including modified system libraries, specific file artifacts in the dalvik-cache directory, and network communications to known C2 infrastructure. Standard Android security tools may not detect firmware-level compromises.

log_sources.description: Monitor for AK_CPP debug log tags and protected broadcast actions (com.action.SystemOptimizeService, com.action.SystemProtectService) indicating Keenadu activity
Inventory corporate-managed Android devices for affected manufacturers and firmware versions; check for presence of suspicious system apps
Monitor for connections to known Keenadu C2 domains (keepgo123.com, gsonx.com, zcnewy.com, trends.search-hub.cn) and Alibaba Cloud CDN endpoints
Check for infection artifacts at /data/dalvik-cache/arm64/system@framework@vndx_10x.jar@classes.jar and presence of libhshelper.so native library

what_to_look_for.description: Core Android runtime library modified to include Keenadu loader code that injects into the Zygote process on boot
Presence of vndx_10x.jar in dalvik-cache directory indicates active Keenadu infection
Network connections to Keenadu C2 infrastructure for module delivery and device registration

what_to_look_for.indicator: AK_CPP debug tags in logcat output
what_to_look_for.description: Debug logging from Keenadu's AKServer and AKClient modules indicating active malware execution
Protected broadcasts used by Keenadu for inter-module communication

immediate_actions.action: Identify affected devices in your environment
immediate_actions.description: Inventory all Android tablets, especially Alldocube models (iPlay 50 mini Pro, iPlay 50 mini Pro NFE). Check firmware build dates and versions. Use MDM to scan for known infection indicators.
On suspected devices, check for Keenadu infection markers in the dalvik-cache directory and logcat output. The presence of vndx_10x.jar or AK_CPP log tags confirms infection.
immediate_actions.command: adb shell ls /data/dalvik-cache/arm64/system@framework@vndx_10x.jar@classes.* && adb logcat -d | grep AK_CPP

immediate_actions.action: Block known C2 domains and IPs
immediate_actions.description: Add Keenadu C2 infrastructure to your network blocklists: domains keepgo123.com, gsonx.com, zcnewy.com, trends.search-hub.cn; IPs 67.198.232.4 and 67.198.232.187.
Uninstall Eoolii, Ziicam, and Eyeplus camera apps if installed. Verify Google Play Protect is enabled. These apps by Hangzhou Denghong Technology Co., Ltd. delivered Keenadu payloads.
immediate_actions.command: adb uninstall com.eoolii.camera && adb uninstall com.ziicam.camera && adb uninstall com.eyeplus.camera

immediate_actions.action: Disable compromised system apps on infected devices
immediate_actions.description: If device replacement is not immediately possible, disable known compromised system apps including the facial recognition service and modified launcher via ADB. Note that firmware-level infection may persist through factory resets.
